description: From Middle English manace, from Old French manace, menace, &c., from Late Latin minācia (“threat, menace”), from Latin mināx (“threatening”) + -ia (“forming abstract nouns”).

examples: the dark menace of the distant war.

entries.meaning: (informal) An annoying and bothersome person or thing.

description: First attested in 1303: from Middle English manacen, from Old French menacer, manecier, manechier and Anglo-Norman manasser, from the assumed Vulgar Latin *mināciāre, from Latin minācia, whence the noun.

verbs.description: menace (third-person singular simple present menaces, present participle menacing, simple past and past participle menaced) (transitive, intransitive)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make threats against (someone); to intimidate.
examples: to menace a country with war

entries.meaning: To threaten (an evil to be inflicted).
To endanger (someone or something); to imperil or jeopardize.
